topic.title: HPE Helion Development Platform 2.0: Java Hello World Sample

body.p: This Servlet-based Java web app displays the text "Hello World!". This is a demonstration of the minimum requirements to build a functional application. Use this sample to ensure that you have set up your environment for deployment to Helion Development Platform.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: If you are missing any of these items, you must install them before continuing.

ul.li: Access to an Application Lifecycle Service (ALS) Cluster
The Helion command-line interface (CLI) must be installed.
Access to the web-based Helion Management Console.

section.title: JDK
section.p: Install the Java Development Kit (JDK) before installing other prerequisites.

section.title: Deploy the Application
section.p: Application Lifecycle Service clusters that require an upstream HTTP proxy to access the internet will need to be made aware of the proxy. The sample applications require access to the Internet in order to download dependent packages.
Use the Helion client to deploy your app to Helion Development Platform.

ol.li: Ensure that you are targeting your desired environment. If you are not, executehelion target https://api.xx.xx.xx.xx.xip.io
Ensure that you are logged in to your desired environment. If you are not, executehelion login
If you are not already there, cd to the root directory of the sample.
Deploy the application by using the command:helion push

Accept any default values that you may be prompted for.By default ALS clusters are configured with two domains (private and public). In some situations the Helion CLI may prompt you to select a target domain. If prompted, select the public domain from the given list (i.e. <app-name>.xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx.xip.io)

section.title: Key Code Snippets
section.p: The POM.xml file contains the configuration information generated by Maven and used by ALS to set up the environment.

ol.li: Open the Helion Management Console. This is the web-based administrative interface that can be reached by typing the ALS endpoint URL into a browser window.
If the file push was successful, you should see hello-world-java in the list of available applications.
The status of the application should be Started. Click the name of the application to launch it.
In the upper right-hand corner, click View App.
You should see a simple text message: Hello World!

section.title: Key Learnings

ol.li: ALS requires configuration information to create an environment for your app. Configuration information is contained in the pom.xml file. Tools like Maven can generate this configuration file for you.
You can deploy your app using either the Helion CLI.
